ASSESSMENTS.title: Start Here – Photo & Checklist
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: Do this quick checklist before you submit your work.

questions.text:
Have you taken a clear photo of your finished project and emailed it to your teacher?

Use this link to upload or check your photo: pukekohetech.github.io/phsphoto
questions.hint: Take a clear photo that shows the whole project from the best angle.
options: Yes – I have taken a clear photo and emailed it to my teacher.
No – I still need to do this.

questions.text:
Have you completed all of the other quizzes and assessments for this unit standard in this app (for example the Materials quiz, Self-reflection, Assessment Record Sheet and any others your teacher has added)?

This checklist will automatically stay up to date as new quizzes and assessments are added to questions.json.
questions.hint: Go back and finish any other quizzes or assessment sheets before you submit.
options: Yes – I have fully completed all the quizzes and assessments in this app.
No – I still have quizzes and assessments to complete.

questions.text: What is the most common exotic timber that is grown in plantations in New Zealand?
questions.hint: See Exotic Softwoods – which plantation timber covers large areas of both islands? (Page 13)

questions.text: Name 2 types of New Zealand native timbers that can be used for high-quality furniture.
questions.hint: See Indigenous timbers (native) – look for the native timbers linked to high-quality or recycled furniture. (Pages 12–13)

questions.text: Name an imported timber that can be used for decking and outdoor furniture.
questions.hint: See Imported hardwoods – look for timbers used for decking and outdoor furniture. (Page 14)

questions.text: Which timber product is commonly used for making kitchen cabinets and has a smooth, paintable surface?
questions.hint: Look in the Manufactured boards section for a timber product made from fine wood fibres with a smooth surface. (Page 19)

questions.text: Name a sheet material that is commonly used for bracing the walls of a house.
questions.hint: See Structural plywood and bracing products used for wall sheathing. (Pages 18–19)

questions.text: What is one key advantage of using engineered timber products like LVL or Glulam?
questions.hint: Look in Engineered timber products – think about strength, stability or ability to span long distances. (Page 20)

rubric.check: long span|can span further|longer lengths|long beams

questions.text: Name a timber treatment level that is suitable for outdoor above-ground use, such as decks and pergolas.
questions.hint: See Hazard classes and treatment – look for the level used for outdoor, above-ground situations. (Page 16)

questions.text: Why is H4 treated timber used for fence posts or in-ground applications?
questions.hint: Think about decay, rot and ground contact. (Page 16)

rubric.check: ground contact|in ground|buried in ground|in the soil
resist rot|resist decay|resist fungi|won't rot|lasts longer|protects against decay

questions.text: What does LOSP stand for, and why might it be chosen instead of traditional water-borne treatments?
questions.hint: See Timber treatments – look for a treatment that uses light organic solvent and think about appearance and moisture. (Page 17)

rubric.check: keeps timber dry|less swelling|less distortion|less movement|no added moisture
clear finish|better appearance|no green stain|easier to paint|good for finishing

questions.text: Name a situation where you would use H1.2 treated timber inside a building.
questions.hint: Look for indoor framing or structural use where there is a risk of borer or fungi, but the timber is not exposed to weather. (Page 16)

rubric.check: not exposed to weather|inside building envelope|dry area

questions.text: What is one reason for choosing a water-based acrylic paint instead of an oil-based paint for interior walls?
questions.hint: Look at the paint comparison – think about smell, drying time and cleaning. (Page 25)

rubric.check: low odour|less smell|fewer fumes|better for indoors
easy clean up with water|water clean up|no turps needed

questions.text: Oil-based polyurethane and water-based polyurethane each have different advantages. Describe one advantage of oil-based polyurethane and one advantage of water-based polyurethane.
questions.hint: Compare the two types in the finishes section – think about durability, colour, and drying time. (Pages 24–25)

questions.text: Identify 3 methods that are commonly used to apply a paint finish.
questions.hint: Look in the Paint application section for the three main methods. (Page 26)

questions.text: When choosing a finish for a kitchen benchtop, why might you choose a two-pack polyurethane rather than a simple oil finish?
questions.hint: Think about durability, heat, water and cleaning. (Page 24)

questions.text: Explain one reason why a clear oil finish (such as Danish oil or linseed oil) might be chosen for a piece of furniture instead of a high build polyurethane.
questions.hint: Think about the look and feel of the wood, and the type of furniture. (Page 24)

rubric.check: easy to repair|easy to recoat|scratches less obvious
